_metadata.description: Component library for radiology reporting. Each component contains multiple picklists with ordered options.

structure.components: One component per anatomic section per modality (e.g., CR-lungsandpleura)
structure.picklists: Each component contains multiple picklists (categories of findings)
structure.options: Each picklist contains ordered options with clinical states
structure.routes_to: Array of template IDs that use this component (dependency tracking)

options.text: Endotracheal tube with tip approximately {{distance}} cm above the carina, in satisfactory position.
ETT tip low, near the carina. Consider slight withdrawal.
ETT tip high, at the level of the thoracic inlet. Consider advancement.
ETT in the right mainstem bronchus. Recommend withdrawal.
Nasogastric tube with tip in the stomach and side port below the GE junction.
Orogastric tube with tip in the stomach.
Enteric tube with tip in the esophagus. Recommend advancement prior to use.
Dobhoff tube with tip in the {{location}}.
Nasojejunal feeding tube with tip in the proximal jejunum.
Enteric tube malpositioned in the tracheobronchial tree. Recommend removal prior to use.
Sengstaken-Blakemore tube in place for variceal bleeding.
Right IJ central venous catheter with tip in the {{location}}.
Left IJ central venous catheter with tip in the {{location}}.
Right subclavian central venous catheter with tip in the {{location}}.
Left subclavian central venous catheter with tip in the {{location}}.
Right PICC line with tip in the {{location}}.
Left PICC line with tip in the {{location}}.
Hickman catheter with tip in the {{location}}.
Central venous catheter with tip malpositioned in the {{malposition}}.
Central venous catheter coiled in the {{location}}.
Central venous catheter tip in the azygos vein.
Central venous catheter crossing to the contralateral brachiocephalic vein.
Central venous catheter tip remaining in the internal jugular vein, not advanced to the SVC.
Left-sided central line with tip in a persistent left SVC.
Right chest tube with tip at the apex.
Left chest tube with tip at the apex.
{{Side}} chest tube with side port projecting outside the thorax.
{{Side}} chest tube with tip at the lung base.
{{Side}} chest tube with tip projecting in the fissure.
{{Side}} chest tube with tip projecting within the lung parenchyma.
{{Side}} chest tube with kink at the entry site.
{{Side}} pigtail catheter in the pleural space.
Single-chamber pacemaker with lead in the right ventricle.
Dual-chamber pacemaker with leads in the right atrium and right ventricle.
Single-chamber ICD with lead in the right ventricle.
Dual-chamber ICD with leads in the right atrium and right ventricle.
Biventricular pacemaker with leads in the RA, RV, and coronary sinus.
Biventricular ICD with leads in the RA, RV, and coronary sinus.
CRT-D (cardiac resynchronization therapy defibrillator) with leads in the RA, RV, and coronary sinus.
Leadless pacemaker in the right ventricle.
Implantable loop recorder in the left parasternal region.
Subcutaneous ICD with lead in the parasternal position.
Twiddler's syndrome with lead retraction and coiling.
Tracheostomy tube in satisfactory position, midway between the stoma and carina.
Tracheostomy tube positioned low, near the carina.
Tracheostomy tube positioned high, near the stoma.
Tracheostomy tube cuff overinflated, distending the tracheal wall.
Swan-Ganz catheter with tip in the {{side}} main pulmonary artery, in satisfactory position.
Swan-Ganz catheter with tip in the proximal {{side}} pulmonary artery.
Swan-Ganz catheter tip positioned distally, beyond the pulmonary hilum. Consider retraction to avoid infarction.
Swan-Ganz catheter with tip in the right atrium, not advanced into the pulmonary artery.
Intra-aortic balloon pump with tip just distal to the left subclavian artery origin, in satisfactory position.
IABP catheter with tip at the aortic knob level.
IABP positioned high, tip at or above the aortic arch. Risk of left subclavian occlusion.
IABP positioned low. Risk of renal or visceral artery occlusion.
Veno-venous ECMO with dual-lumen cannula in the right IJ. Tip in the right atrium/IVC junction.
Veno-venous ECMO with drainage cannula via femoral vein and return cannula via right IJ.
Veno-arterial ECMO with venous drainage cannula and arterial return cannula in place.
Central VA-ECMO with cannulas placed via sternotomy.
Impella device with inlet in the left ventricle and outlet in the ascending aorta.
Impella CP in satisfactory position across the aortic valve.
Impella 5.0/5.5 in place via axillary approach.
Left ventricular assist device (LVAD) with inflow cannula in the LV apex and outflow graft to the ascending aorta.
Right IJ tunneled dialysis catheter with tip in the {{location}}.
Left IJ tunneled dialysis catheter with tip in the {{location}}.
Right subclavian dialysis catheter with tip in the {{location}}.
Temporary hemodialysis catheter via {{approach}} with tip in the {{location}}.
Dialysis catheter tip malpositioned in the {{location}}.
Mediastinal drains in place, status post sternotomy.
Transvenous temporary pacing wire with tip in the right ventricular apex.
Epicardial pacing wires, status post cardiac surgery.
Temporary pacing wire coiled in the right atrium.
Surgical clips in the mediastinum, status post CABG.
VP shunt tubing in the right upper quadrant.
Support devices are unchanged in position.
Lines and tubes are in stable satisfactory position.
Support devices are appropriately positioned as detailed above.
Evaluation of support device positions limited by patient positioning.

CR-lungsandpleura.description: Lung parenchyma and pleural spaces on chest radiograph

options.text: The lungs are clear without focal consolidation, pleural effusion, or pneumothorax.
{{Location}} consolidation with air bronchograms, compatible with pneumonia.
{{Location}} pulmonary nodule. CT recommended for further evaluation.
{{Location}} pulmonary mass. CT recommended for further evaluation.
Flattened diaphragms and hyperexpanded lungs, consistent with COPD.
Blunting of the {{side}} costophrenic angle, may represent small effusion.
Right tension pneumothorax with mediastinal shift to the left.
Left tension pneumothorax with mediastinal shift to the right.
Calcified pleural plaques, which may be related to prior asbestos exposure.

CR-heartmediastinum.description: Cardiac silhouette and mediastinal contours on chest radiograph

options.text: Enlarged cardiac silhouette, which may be accentuated by AP portable technique.
Widened mediastinum, likely due to unfolded aorta.
Prominent mediastinum, which may be related to patient positioning and body habitus.
Atherosclerotic calcification of the aortic arch.
Degenerative changes of the thoracic spine.
Lytic lesion in the {{location}}. Consider further evaluation.

CR-softtissue.description: Soft tissue findings on chest radiograph

AR-bowelgas.description: Bowel gas distribution on abdominal radiograph

options.text: Ileus with diffusely dilated loops of bowel.
Dilated loops of small bowel with air-fluid levels, consistent with small bowel obstruction.
Small bowel obstruction pattern with paucity of distal gas.
Findings concerning for small bowel obstruction. CT recommended for further evaluation.
Dilated colon, concerning for large bowel obstruction.
Marked colonic distention. Consider LBO versus toxic megacolon.
Free air under the diaphragm, concerning for bowel perforation.
Small amount of free air, which may be postoperative in the appropriate clinical setting.

AR-solidorgans.description: Solid organ shadows and calcifications on abdominal radiograph

options.text: Pancreatic calcifications, consistent with chronic pancreatitis.
Degenerative changes of the lumbar spine.
Degenerative changes of the SI joints.
Findings suggestive of Le Fort fracture. CT recommended.
Limited evaluation of sinuses on plain radiograph.
Retention cyst or polyp in the {{side}} {{sinus}} sinus.

XR-airway.description: Soft tissue neck and airway on radiograph

options.text: The airway is patent. No prevertebral soft tissue swelling.
Patent airway without evidence of epiglottitis or croup.
Steeple sign with subglottic narrowing, compatible with croup.
Thickened epiglottis (thumb sign), concerning for epiglottitis.
Widened prevertebral soft tissues, may represent retropharyngeal swelling/abscess.
Radiopaque foreign body at the level of {{location}}.
Degenerative changes of the glenohumeral joint.
Calcific tendinosis of the supraspinatus tendon.
Elbow joint effusion with elevated fat pads, may indicate occult fracture.
Colles fracture (dorsally angulated distal radius fracture).
Smith fracture (volarly angulated distal radius fracture).
Scaphoid fracture. Consider follow-up imaging if clinical concern remains.
No definite fracture. Clinical concern for scaphoid fracture - consider MRI or follow-up radiographs.
Mallet finger with avulsion of the distal phalanx.
Degenerative changes, most prominent at the {{joint}}.
Erosive changes suggestive of inflammatory arthropathy.
Changes suggestive of avascular necrosis of the {{side}} femoral head.
{{Side}} hip degenerative changes with joint space narrowing.
SI joint fusion, may be related to prior ankylosing spondylitis.
{{Side}} total hip arthroplasty without hardware complication.
Segond fracture (lateral tibial plateau avulsion), associated with ACL tear.
Total knee arthroplasty without hardware complication.
Proximal fibula fracture (evaluate for Maisonneuve injury).
Findings concerning for Lisfranc injury. CT or weight-bearing views recommended.
No acute fracture or malalignment. Normal cervical lordosis.
Limited evaluation due to patient positioning. CT recommended if clinical concern.
Loss of normal cervical lordosis, may be positional or due to muscle spasm.
Fracture of {{level}}. Consider CT for further characterization.
Multilevel degenerative disc disease and spondylosis.
No acute fracture. Normal thoracic kyphosis.
Compression fracture of {{level}} with {{percent}}% height loss.
Mild anterior wedging of {{level}}, likely chronic.
No acute fracture. Normal lumbar lordosis.
Loss of normal lumbar lordosis, may be due to muscle spasm.
Compression fracture of {{level}} with {{percent}}% height loss.
Grade {{grade}} anterolisthesis of {{level}}, likely degenerative spondylolisthesis.
Pars defect at {{level}}, consistent with spondylolysis.
Multilevel degenerative disc disease and facet arthropathy.

CT-brainparenchyma.description: Brain parenchyma findings on CT head

options.text: No hemorrhage, mass, or acute territorial infarct.
Acute intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the {{location}}, measuring approximately {{size}}.
Hypodensity in the {{territory}} concerning for acute/subacute infarct.
Loss of gray-white differentiation in the {{location}}, concerning for acute infarct.
Chronic infarct in the {{location}} with encephalomalacia.
Cerebral volume loss greater than expected for stated age.
{{Degree}} periventricular white matter hypodensities, likely chronic microvascular ischemic changes.
{{Size}} mass in the {{location}}. MRI recommended for further evaluation.
No mass effect or midline shift.

CT-ventricles.description: Ventricles and extra-axial findings on CT head

options.text: Ventricles are normal in size and configuration.
Enlarged ventricles out of proportion to sulcal prominence, may represent NPH.
Obstructive hydrocephalus with dilated lateral and third ventricles.
Acute subdural hematoma along the {{location}}, measuring up to {{thickness}} mm.
Mixed-density subdural collection suggesting acute-on-chronic subdural hematoma.

CT-calvarium.description: Skull and paranasal sinuses on CT head

options.text: Opacification of the {{side}} mastoid air cells.

CT-pulmonaryarteries.description: Pulmonary artery findings for CTA PE protocol

options.text: Pulmonary arteries are patent without filling defect.
Pulmonary arteries are well opacified without filling defect to the segmental level.
Saddle pulmonary embolism straddling the main pulmonary artery bifurcation.
Chronic pulmonary embolism with eccentric filling defect in the {{location}}.
No CT evidence of right heart strain.
CT findings suggest right heart strain with RV/LV ratio greater than 1.
Interventricular septal bowing suggesting right heart strain.
{{Location}} consolidation with air bronchograms, compatible with pneumonia.

followup: Follow-up CT recommended per Fleischner guidelines

options.text: {{Side}} pleural effusion with adjacent compressive atelectasis.

CT-heartmediastinum.description: Cardiac and mediastinal findings on CT chest

options.text: No mediastinal lymphadenopathy by size criteria.
{{Location}} lymphadenopathy, largest measuring {{size}} cm in short axis.
Mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy. Differential includes malignancy, sarcoidosis, or infection.
Thoracic aorta is normal in caliber.
Endotracheal tube tip low, at or near the carina.
Endotracheal tube in the right mainstem bronchus.
Enteric tube with tip in the stomach.
Feeding tube with tip in the duodenum.
Feeding tube with tip in the proximal jejunum.
GJ tube with gastric and jejunal ports.
Enteric tube tip in the esophagus.
Enteric tube coiled in the stomach.
Right IJ central venous catheter with tip in the SVC.
Left IJ central venous catheter with tip in the SVC.
Right subclavian central venous catheter with tip in the SVC.
Left subclavian central venous catheter with tip in the SVC.
Right PICC line with tip in the SVC.
Left PICC line with tip in the SVC.
Port-a-cath with tip in the SVC.
Dialysis catheter with tip at the cavoatrial junction.
Central venous catheter tip in the right atrium.
Central venous catheter tip in the azygos vein.
Left-sided catheter in a persistent left SVC.
Right chest tube in the pleural space.
Left chest tube in the pleural space.
Chest tube with tip in the fissure.
Chest tube with tip in the lung parenchyma.
Pacemaker lead in the right ventricle.
Pacemaker lead in the right atrium.
Swan-Ganz catheter with tip in the right pulmonary artery.
Swan-Ganz catheter with tip in the left pulmonary artery.
Swan-Ganz catheter with tip in the main pulmonary artery.
Intra-aortic balloon pump with tip at the aortic isthmus.
Impella device across the aortic valve.
LVAD with inflow cannula in the LV apex and outflow to the ascending aorta.
Foley catheter with balloon in the bladder.
Liver is normal in size and attenuation.
{{Size}} cm hypodense hepatic lesion, too small to characterize.
{{Size}} cm indeterminate hepatic lesion. MRI recommended for further characterization.

CT-gallbladder.description: Gallbladder and biliary findings on CT abdomen

options.text: No gallbladder wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid.
Gallstones without CT evidence of cholecystitis.
Findings concerning for acute cholecystitis: gallbladder distension, wall thickening, and pericholecystic fat stranding.
Common bile duct is normal in caliber.
Dilated common bile duct measuring {{size}} mm.
Mild CBD dilatation, may be normal post-cholecystectomy.
Findings of acute pancreatitis with peripancreatic fat stranding.
Necrotizing pancreatitis with {{extent}} of pancreatic necrosis.

CT-kidneys.description: Renal and ureteral findings on CT abdomen

options.text: Kidneys are normal in size and appearance.
{{Size}} mm {{side}} ureteral stone at the {{location}} with proximal hydroureteronephrosis.

CT-bowel.description: GI tract findings on CT abdomen/pelvis

options.text: No bowel obstruction, wall thickening, or inflammatory change.
Small bowel obstruction with transition point in the {{location}}.
High-grade small bowel obstruction with dilated proximal loops measuring up to {{size}} cm.
Closed-loop small bowel obstruction. Surgical consultation recommended.
Acute appendicitis with dilated appendix measuring {{size}} mm and periappendiceal fat stranding.
{{Distribution}} colonic wall thickening, consistent with colitis.

CT-peritoneum.description: Peritoneal and free fluid findings on CT abdomen/pelvis

options.text: No free intraperitoneal fluid or air.
Small amount of free air, may be postoperative in appropriate setting.
Omental caking, concerning for peritoneal carcinomatosis.

CT-face-sinuses.description: CT findings of facial bones and paranasal sinuses

options.text: Air-fluid level in the {{side}} {{sinus}} sinus, may represent acute sinusitis or blood.
No acute soft tissue abnormality in the neck.
{{Size}} rim-enhancing collection in the {{location}}, concerning for abscess.
Inflammatory changes in the {{location}}, may represent phlegmon.
{{Size}} thyroid nodule. Ultrasound recommended for further evaluation.
No acute fracture or malalignment of the cervical spine.
Patent arterial system without significant stenosis.
Atherosclerotic calcification of the abdominal aorta.
{{Degree}} stenosis of the {{side}} superficial femoral artery.
Occlusion of the {{side}} superficial femoral artery with reconstitution via collaterals.
Multivessel disease of the {{side}} tibial trifurcation vessels.
Single vessel runoff to the {{side}} foot via the {{vessel}}.
Liver is normal in size and echogenicity.
Homogeneous hepatic echotexture without focal lesion.
Increased hepatic echogenicity consistent with hepatic steatosis.
{{Size}} cm echogenic hepatic lesion, compatible with hemangioma.
{{Size}} cm {{characteristics}} hepatic lesion. Further evaluation recommended.
Gallbladder is normal without stones or wall thickening.
Cholelithiasis without sonographic evidence of cholecystitis.
Findings consistent with acute cholecystitis: positive sonographic Murphy sign, gallstones, and wall thickening.
Gallbladder wall thickening, which may be seen with {{etiology}}.
Common bile duct measures {{size}} mm, within normal limits.
Common bile duct is normal in caliber.
Dilated common bile duct measuring {{size}} mm.
Common bile duct measures {{size}} mm, may be normal post-cholecystectomy.
Kidneys are normal in size and echogenicity bilaterally.
Right kidney measures {{right}} cm. Left kidney measures {{left}} cm.
{{Side}} renal stone measuring {{size}} mm with posterior acoustic shadowing.
Increased renal echogenicity, which may indicate medical renal disease.
{{Side}} renal mass measuring {{size}} cm. CT recommended.
No hemodynamically significant stenosis of the carotid arteries bilaterally.
Bilateral carotid arteries are patent with normal velocities.
{{Side}} carotid bifurcation plaque without hemodynamically significant stenosis.
Calcified plaque at the {{side}} carotid bulb.
{{Degree}} {{side}} ICA stenosis with PSV of {{psv}} cm/s.
No deep venous thrombosis in the {{side}} lower extremity.
Deep veins of the {{side}} leg are patent and compressible with normal augmentation.
Acute deep venous thrombosis in the {{side}} {{vein}}.
Non-compressible {{vein}} with echogenic thrombus, consistent with acute DVT.
DVT extending from the {{proximal}} to the {{distal}}.
Chronic DVT in the {{side}} {{vein}} with partial recanalization.
{{Side}} great saphenous vein thrombosis extending to within {{distance}} cm of the saphenofemoral junction.
Superficial venous thrombosis. No deep venous thrombosis.
Normal thyroid gland without discrete nodules.
Small thyroid gland, may represent atrophy.
{{Side}} suspicious thyroid nodule measuring {{size}}, TI-RADS {{category}}, FNA recommended.
Diffusely heterogeneous thyroid with pseudonodules, suggestive of Hashimoto thyroiditis.
Endometrium measures {{thickness}} mm, normal for {{phase}} phase.
{{Side}} complex cyst measuring {{size}}. Consider MRI for further characterization.
No discrete mass or fluid collection.
{{Size}} oval, echogenic, compressible mass consistent with lipoma.
{{Size}} complex fluid collection with surrounding hyperemia, concerning for abscess.
{{Size}} solid mass in the {{location}}. Further evaluation recommended.
Subcutaneous edema consistent with cellulitis. No drainable fluid collection.
Normal ventilation-perfusion scan. Low probability for pulmonary embolism.
Matched ventilation-perfusion defects. Low probability for acute PE.
Indeterminate study. Consider CTA if clinically indicated.
Multiple segmental perfusion defects with normal ventilation (mismatched defects). High probability for PE.
Large mismatched perfusion defect in the {{location}}. High probability for PE.
Normal hepatobiliary scan. Gallbladder visualized. No evidence of acute cholecystitis.
Normal hepatobiliary scan. Gallbladder ejection fraction of {{ef}}% (normal >35%).
Non-visualization of the gallbladder at {{time}}, consistent with acute cholecystitis.
Gallbladder not visualized after morphine augmentation. Findings consistent with acute cholecystitis.
Gallbladder ejection fraction of {{ef}}% (normal >35%), consistent with biliary dyskinesia.
Delayed gallbladder visualization. Consider chronic cholecystitis.

_summary.structure: Modality â†’ Region â†’ Component Templates â†’ Picklists â†’ Options
_summary.design: Each component template (e.g., CR-lungsandpleura) contains multiple picklists with normal + all abnormal options for that anatomy on that modality

options.text: No significant disc disease or spinal stenosis.
Abnormal cord signal at {{level}}, may represent myelopathy.
No significant disc disease or spinal stenosis.
Medial and lateral menisci are intact.
Degenerative signal in the medial meniscus without definite tear.
Degenerative signal in the lateral meniscus without definite tear.
ACL, PCL, MCL, and LCL are intact.
